title: feat: Add Swipe to Navigate for macOS touchpads.
author: seivan
body:
Edit: [Alternative implementation](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/262262) registers the swipe recognizers and expose them as an extension API instead: 

Following options have been added:

- 	`"disabled"` â€“ Disable swipe navigation.
- 	`"editor"` â€“ Switch editor tabs across all groups (previous/next).
- 	`"editorInGroup"` â€“ Switch editor tabs within the current group only (previous/next).
- 	`"history"` â€“ Move through most recently used editors (MRU) across all groups (previous/next).
- 	`"historyInGroup"` â€“ Move through most recently used editors (MRU) within the current group (previous/next).
- 	`"group"` â€“ Change focus to neighboring editor groups (left/right/up/down).
- 	`"navigation"` â€“ Move through navigational history (for example: Go To References).
- 	`"edit"` â€“ Navigate cursor edit locations.
- 	`"navigationEdit"` â€“ Navigate through a combined history of navigation and edit locations.

Alternatively, the setting can be defined as an object:

```json 
"workbench.editor.swipeToNavigate": {
  "horizontal": "navigationEdit",
  "vertical": "disabled"
}
```

Can also support custom actions: 
```json
"workbench.editor.swipeToNavigate": {
  "horizontal": "disabled",
  "vertical": { "previous": "commandId1", "next": "commandId2" }
}
```

Requires these OS settings: 
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/09e72ba6-7ae2-467f-b379-dde1b9455ae2)

Older OS settings: 
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/895e540f-dc46-4d18-9f7a-7aa0516cebbc)


Also I think there is a misunderstanding in previous threads, swipes don't work unless you activate them on OS level (as per screenshot). There is a distinction between swiping and panning, the latter is fullscreen.  
It is very possible that you had [disabled](https://github.com/electron/electron/issues/19131#issuecomment-613751165) them on your OS level and assumed they didn't work.

Previous discussions with @bpasero indicated there was no interest in adding more Electron APIs. However, Electron applications such as Discord have supported swipe gestures for years without issues, and Touch Bar integration is already supported and that uses Electron APIs. Swipe gestures have been stable in Electron for a long time and have not caused problems, outside of that misunderstanding

~~Another option would be to expose events for extensions, though I am not sure how to get started with that. I assume it would require approval before introducing a new extension API.~~

I previously attempted this through an [extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=Seivan.swipe-to-navigate), but it relied on heavy hacks and monkey-patching the bootloader. These broke with every VS Code update and were difficult to maintain, since I had to inspect the generated JavaScript to figure out where to apply the patches. This approach is unsustainable.

I rely on swipe gestures for navigation as an accessibility feature. Swiping to move between views is a native macOS behavior supported in Xcode, Safari, Finder, Terminal, Notes, and more. The lack of support in VS Code feels inconsistent with the platform.

At the very least, the swipe gesture recognizers should be exposed via an extension like the alternative PR https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/262262 and let extensions (I've done one) define actions for them. 

Discussions:
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/4803 (again)
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/40526
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/25447
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/25325
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/25449

title: Fix: clear duplicate-casing errors after case-only file renames on Windows (closes #261995)
author: kzekiue
body: On case-insensitive file systems (Windows for example) renaming a file by only changing its letter-case ~ for example `page1.js` => `Page1.js` ~ confuses `tsserver`. It continues to hold both casings in the program and surfaces errors such as: The error persists until the user manually restarts the TS server or reloads VS Code (see bug #261995). ### RCA File-watcher stacks donâ€™t always emit a delete => create sequence for a case-only rename on case-insensitive FSs. `tsserver` therefore never drops the old path and thinks the file is duplicated. ### Testing * Verified on Windows 11. ### Files changed * `extensions/typescript-language-features/src/languageFeatures/updatePathsOnRename.ts` * `extensions/typescript-language-features/src/typeScriptServiceClientHost.ts` --- Closes #261995

title: Add initial MCP server
author: TylerLeonhardt
body:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->
This adds a playwright based vscode developement MCP server to allow Agent mode the ability to _see_ the changes it's making.

The steps to use this should be simple:
* npm i
* Launch the `Launch MCP Server` task
* Start the server via the `mcp.json` in the workspace

There are some known issues:
1. clicking isn't working... this could be a bug in how I'm holding playwright, or there's a bug there
2. the browser is launched on initialize but really it should be launched, on first use of a real tool

Extracted from https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/261148

universal build has option to skip lipo step for mach-o files that are declared present as same arch on both packages. However it requires a sha256 comparison to ensure the files are same, currently this logic fails since we publishing the unsigned archive after the hardened entitlement step which will change file sha, this PR publishes the unsigned archive for universal step before entitlement step and additionally repackages the client after entitlement under a different name for the codesign step to make sure they aren't mixed.

```
(Pipeline.Workspace)/vscode_client_darwin_$(VSCODE_ARCH)_archive - points to archive that will be codesigned and has hardened entitlement
$(Pipeline.Workspace)/unsigned_vscode_client_darwin_$(VSCODE_ARCH)_archive - points to archive without any codesign and entitlements
```

title: render token usage
author: isidorn
body:
Fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/248860

This is a first stab at rendering token usage in Chat. Feedback is very much welcome. Open questinos:
1) Do we already have a utility that summs up all the tokens in the session (I could not find it, so I am manully implementing it in the renderer). I would love to simplify this.
2) I am not a fan of "(preview)(0x)" rendering - double brackets. Ideas on what better to do are welcome

Next steps are to colour this in some warning colour once we are above 85%. @roblourens I think that is the limit you use for summarization 

I was not convinced where to render the token usage, but after much delibaration I think showing it only on the last request actually works nicely. E.g. then it is more married to the session than to the actual request (hopefully).

Justin if you do not like the implementation let me know and I can start over - I tried to keep it minimal.

title: Fix OAuth2 resource parameter compliance with RFC 8707
author: bluedog13
body:
## Summary

This PR fixes VS Code's OAuth2 flow to comply with RFC 8707 by including the resource parameter in token exchange requests.

## Problem

The current implementation includes the resource indicator in the authorization request but omits it from both the authorization code and refresh token exchange requests. This violates RFC 8707 and can cause token validation failures on protected resources that require the resource parameter to be consistently present throughout the OAuth2 flow.

## Solution

Added the resource parameter to both token exchange methods in the `DynamicAuthProvider` class:
- `exchangeCodeForToken()` - now includes resource parameter when exchanging authorization code for tokens
- `exchangeRefreshTokenForToken()` - now includes resource parameter when refreshing tokens

The fix ensures that when `_resourceMetadata?.resource` is available, it is consistently included in all OAuth2 requests throughout the authentication flow.

## Test Plan

- [x] Verified the fix addresses the specific code location mentioned in #261364 (line 599 in extHostAuthentication.ts)
- [x] Ensured the resource parameter is added in both token exchange scenarios
- [x] Confirmed the implementation follows the same pattern as the existing authorization request code

Fixes #261364

title: Add Open Active Diff Side option to Command Palette using DIFF_OPEN_SIDE command
author: LeftPhalange
body: Addresses issue #260762. This adds the `workbench.action.compareEditor.openSide` or `DIFF_OPEN_SIDE` constant in to the `MenuRegistry`, which registers it into the Command Palette. Below is a screenshot showing it in the command palette. ## How to Test 1. Open Visual Studio Code. 2. Open a folder with two files. 3. Select one file for compare in the Explorer pane by right-clicking it and click `Select for Compare` in the context menu. 4. Select another file by right-clicking it and clicking on `Compare with Selected` in the context menu. 5. The diff viewer should now open. Click on one of the file editors. This can be either side. 6. Open the Command Palette by hitting CTRL + SHIFT + P (Command/Cmd for Mac, instead of CTRL). 7. Look for "Open File on Selected Side". Click it while the desired file editor on either side is selected. 8. The desired file should be opened on its own.

title: Add mouse drag scrolling to scrollable element and hover widget
author: LeftPhalange
body:
Adds functionality based on issue #239704.

This PR adds `AbstractScrollableElement` functionality to include mouse drag scrolling in the hover widget. By default, `handleDragScroll` is disabled and will not be triggered in the main editor view. This is selectively enabled within the `ui/hover/hoverWidget` component.

## Demonstration

![Recording 2025-08-12 215730](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/110aad6b-c58d-4bd5-8d8c-71e248239e09)

## How to test
In Visual Studio Code, hover over some text that has a definition, or anything that triggers the `HoverWidget`. Press and hold the left mouse button anywhere in the text inside the hover info widget, and move the mouse up to the top, or the bottom of it. You can also scroll from left to right.

title: Disable none shell integration message
author: Tyriar
body:
Part of #260880

This is a minimal defensive fix for #260880 where we just disable the message about no shell integration.

This is another hard to reproduce and verify problem and the actual suspected fix is much riskier in a pretty critical part of code that runs before every new chat terminal is created: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/261202. Right now telemetry shows similar numbers for no shell integration in the old extension tool and the new core one, so this is the safest approach and we can look into the impact of "the real" fix in Insiders.

title: Workaround electron proxy issues for GitHub by allowing to switch to node's fetch
author: TylerLeonhardt
body:
A user reported that their proxy ZScaller has issues with Electron's fetch. More research needs to be done to understand why this is not playing nice wholistically...

... but, to unblock GitHub scenarios like Copilot, we add this setting to change the implementation of fetch used.

At some point, we need to have http.useElectronFetch setting be enabled by default and when that happens, this setting can be removed in favor of that.

cc @chrmarti @alexdima

title: Add Python activate hooks into shell integration scripts
author: anthonykim1
body:
Resolves: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/259637 

Important things to note: 
* Update all four shell integration scripts (pwsh, zsh, bash, fish) ---> Done
* Sanitize in process.ts and terminalSuggest.main.ts ---> Done
* If activate returns non-zero (failed), we should prevent crash, catch exit code, and print to terminal 
   ---> Findings: Try catch was not available for zsh, bash so using negate to prevent crash. Fish doesn't crash on eval 
   ---> Try catch was available in pwsh
   ---> Done
* Block other extension from modifying Python specific activate (Important -> Should do this as activate var is leading to code execution)  ---> Done
* Have `*` icon similar to terminal restored message. ---> Done
* Sanitize and remove hard-coded vsc python env var in terminalEnv ---> Done
* Clean-ups ---> Done?

title: AI and Human Edit diffs, also available to extensions, and visual feedback option
author: Splashdamage115
body:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->
**Issue**

[Listener to identify Human VS AI changes #259077](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/259077)

**Description**
This is a comprehensive system for checking differences between human and AI edits. It is formatted as follows:

#### __1. Core Classes and Enums__

- __`LineEditSource` enum__ (`src/vs/editor/common/lineEditSource.ts`):

  - `Undetermined = 0` - Unknown or untracked edit source
  - `Human = 1` - Last edited by human user
  - `AI = 2` - Last edited by AI/automated tools

- __`LineEditTracker` class__ (`src/vs/editor/common/model/lineEditTracker.ts`):

  - Tracks edit sources for each line in a text model
  - Memory-efficient (only stores non-undetermined lines)
  - Handles complex editing operations (insertions, deletions, line merges)
  - Event-driven with `onDidChangeLineEditSources` event

- __`TextModelEditSource` class__ (`src/vs/editor/common/textModelEditSource.ts`):

  - Comprehensive edit source classification system
  - Supports metadata for detailed edit tracking
  - AI extension detection with known extension patterns

#### __2. Features__

1. __Edit Source Classification__:

   - Human operations: typing, pasting, cutting, command execution
   - AI operations: inline completions, chat edits, known AI extensions
   - Separate AI extension detection (Cline, Copilot, Continue, etc.) (this is for non standard input, like that done by Cline)

2. __Edit Handling__:

   - Line insertions with proper line number shifting
   - Partial and full line deletions
   - Line merging operations
   - Multi-line replacements
   - Edit source priority resolution (Human > AI > Undetermined)

3. __Memory Optimization__:

   - Only stores determined line sources
   - Automatic cleanup of deleted lines
   - line number shifting algorithms

4. __Persistence Support__:

   - Serialization/deserialization for state persistence
   - Validation for serialized data
   - Graceful handling of invalid data

#### __3. API Integration__

- __Main Thread API__ (`src/vs/workbench/api/browser/mainThreadBulkEdits.ts`):

  - `MainThreadLineEditTracker` for accessing line edit sources
  - Extension context integration for accurate AI detection
  - Bulk edit operations with proper source attribution

- __Extension Host Protocol__ (`src/vs/workbench/api/common/extHost.protocol.ts`):

  - `ILineEditSourcesChangeData` interface for change events
  - Protocol definitions for main/extension host communication

### __Using the API__

#### __1. Basic Line Edit Source Querying__

```typescript
// Get edit source for a specific line
const editSource = textModel.getLineEditSource(lineNumber);
// Returns: LineEditSource.Human, LineEditSource.AI, or LineEditSource.Undetermined

// Get all tracked line edit sources
const allSources = textModel.getAllLineEditSources();
// Returns: Map<number, LineEditSource>
```

#### __2. Listening to Changes__

```typescript
// Listen for line edit source changes
const disposable = textModel.onDidChangeLineEditSources((event) => {
  event.changes.forEach((source, lineNumber) => {
    console.log(`Line ${lineNumber} edit source changed to ${source}`);
  });
});

// always Dispose
disposable.dispose();
```

#### __3. Making Edits with Proper Source Attribution__

```typescript
// Human edit
textModel.pushEditOperations(null, edits, null, undefined, 
  EditSources.cursor({ kind: 'type' }));

// AI edit from inline completion
textModel.pushEditOperations(null, edits, null, undefined, 
  EditSources.inlineCompletionAccept({
    nes: false,
    requestUuid: 'unique-id',
    languageId: 'typescript',
    providerId: undefined
  }));

// Extension-based AI edit
textModel.pushEditOperations(null, edits, null, undefined, 
  EditSources.extensionApplyEdits({
    extensionId: 'cline.cline',
    extensionName: 'Cline',
    isAiTool: true
  }));
```

#### __4. API Usage__

```typescript
// Clear all line edit sources
textModel.getLineEditTracker().clear();

// Serialize for persistence
const serializedData = textModel.getLineEditTracker().serialize();

// Restore from serialized data
textModel.getLineEditTracker().deserialize(serializedData);

// Direct tracker access
const tracker = textModel.getLineEditTracker();
tracker.handleContentChanges(changes, editSources);
```

### __Line Edit Visual Indicator__
__1. Enable/Disable Commands:__

```typescript
// Commands available in Command Palette:
- "Enable Line Edit Indicators" (editor.action.lineEditIndicator.enable)
- "Disable Line Edit Indicators" (editor.action.lineEditIndicator.disable)  
- "Toggle Line Edit Indicators" (editor.action.lineEditIndicator.toggle)
```

__2. Programmatic Control:__

```typescript
// Get the contribution
const contribution = LineEditIndicatorContribution.get(editor);

// Enable indicators
contribution.enable();

// Disable indicators  
contribution.disable();

// Toggle indicators
contribution.toggle();

// Check if enabled
const isEnabled = contribution.isEnabled();
```

__3. Default Behavior:__

- __Disabled by default__ - must be explicitly enabled
- __Real-time updates__ - indicators update immediately as edits are made
- __Undetermined lines__ - no indicator

### __API Usage Examples__

#### __1. Basic Line Edit Tracking__

```typescript
// Query line edit sources
const editSource = textModel.getLineEditSource(5); // LineEditSource.Human | AI | Undetermined
const allSources = textModel.getAllLineEditSources(); // Map<number, LineEditSource>

// Listen for changes
const disposable = textModel.onDidChangeLineEditSources((event) => {
  event.changes.forEach((source, lineNumber) => {
    console.log(`Line ${lineNumber} changed to ${source}`);
  });
});
```

#### __2. Making Tracked Edits__

```typescript
// Human edit
textModel.pushEditOperations(null, edits, null, undefined, 
  EditSources.cursor({ kind: 'type' }));

// AI edit  
textModel.pushEditOperations(null, edits, null, undefined, 
  EditSources.inlineCompletionAccept({
    nes: false,
    requestUuid: 'uuid',
    languageId: 'typescript',
    providerId: undefined
  }));

// Extension AI edit
textModel.pushEditOperations(null, edits, null, undefined, 
  EditSources.extensionApplyEdits({
    extensionId: 'cline.cline',
    extensionName: 'Cline',
    isAiTool: true
  }));
```

#### __3. Visual Indicator Management__

```typescript
// Enable visual indicators
const contribution = LineEditIndicatorContribution.get(editor);
contribution.enable();

// The indicators will automatically:
// - Show red triangles for human-edited lines
// - Show blue triangles for AI-edited lines  
// - Update in real-time as edits are made
// - Display tooltips on hover
```


**How to test**

Tests for the API and line edits have been added

title: win: self-heal missing 'Open with Code' context menu entries after background update
author: yensubldg
body:
Adds self-heal logic in build/win32/code.iss to restore missing â€œOpen with Codeâ€ context menu registry entries when they disappear after a silent/background update.

**Summary**
- Runs in CurStepChanged at ssPostInstall.
- Recreates file, directory, background, drive verbs if tasks previously selected (or keys existed) and theyâ€™re now missing.
- Skips Windows 11 Insiders AppX scenario (existing conditional preserved).
- Logs healing actions; wrapped in try/except to avoid installer failure.

**Rationale**
Users reported losing context menu entries post update; manual PowerShell restore works. This mitigates by automatically re-creating keys.

**Test Plan**
1. Install with context menu tasks selected.
2. Delete keys:
   HKCR\*\shell\VSCode
   HKCR\Directory\shell\VSCode
   HKCR\Directory\Background\shell\VSCode
3. Run updated installer with /VERYSILENT /UPDATE=1.
4. Verify keys restored and installer log contains â€œHealing VS Code ...â€.
5. Confirm no effect if keys present (idempotent) or tasks never chosen.

**Risk**
Low: only writes when keys missing; avoids Insiders AppX path; catches exceptions.

**Follow-ups**
Possible telemetry or unify with modern Windows 11 integration later.

title: build/npm: add explicit npm version validation in preinstall.js (mirrors Node.js check)
author: ali90h
body:
# Summary

This PR addresses issue [[#252372] by adding explicit npm version validation to the existing `build/npm/preinstall.js` script, following the maintainer preference outlined in the issue discussion.

## Changes Made

- **This PR modifies only** `build/npm/preinstall.js`.
- **Extended existing Node.js validation logic** in `build/npm/preinstall.js` to include npm version checking
- **Added `VSCODE_SKIP_NPM_VERSION_CHECK` environment variable** for consistency with existing `VSCODE_SKIP_NODE_VERSION_CHECK`
- **Set minimum npm version requirement to v10.8.0** *(chosen to align with the current Node requirement; happy to adjust if the team prefers)*
- **Maintained identical error messaging patterns** using ANSI colors and consistent formatting
- **Added robust error handling** for npm unavailability and version parsing failures
- **Preserved all existing functionality** while seamlessly integrating npm validation


## Implementation Details

### Approach Rationale
- **Centralized validation**: Keeps all version enforcement in single `preinstall.js` file as preferred by maintainers
- **No `engines` field**: Avoids adding `engines` to `package.json` to prevent maintenance overhead from multiple sources of truth
- **Consistent patterns**: Reuses exact same regex parsing, comparison logic, and error styling as existing Node validation

### Technical Implementation
```javascript
// Uses same regex-based parsing as Node validation
const npmVersion = /^(\d+)\.(\d+)\.(\d+)/.exec(npmVersionOutput.trim());

// Maintains identical comparison logic
if (majorNpmVersion < 10 || (majorNpmVersion === 10 && minorNpmVersion < 8)) {
    console.error('\x1b[1;31m*** Please use npm v10.8.0 or later for development.\x1b[0;0m');
    throw new Error();
}
```

### Error Messages
- **Availability check**: "npm is not available. Please ensure npm is installed and available in PATH."
- **Version requirement**: "Please use npm v10.8.0 or later for development."
- **Upgrade guidance**: "Run 'npm install -g npm@latest' to update npm to the latest version."

## Testing

- [x] Verified with npm 10.8.0+ (passes validation)
- [x] Verified with npm < 10.8.0 (fails with appropriate error)
- [x] Verified with npm unavailable (fails with clear error message)
- [x] Confirmed `VSCODE_SKIP_NPM_VERSION_CHECK=true` bypasses validation
- [x] Ensured all existing functionality remains unchanged
- [x] Validated error message formatting matches existing Node validation

## Verification (manual)
### Fail (old npm):
```bash
REAL_NPM="$(command -v npm)"
mkdir -p /tmp/npmshim
cat > /tmp/npmshim/npm <<SH
#!/usr/bin/env bash
if [[ "$1" == "--version" ]]; then
  echo 10.7.9
  exit 0
fi
exec "$REAL_NPM" "$@"
SH
chmod +x /tmp/npmshim/npm

PATH="/tmp/npmshim:$PATH" npm install
# Expect: "*** Please use npm v10.8.0 or later for development." and exit
```
### Pass (compatible npm):
```bash
rm -rf /tmp/npmshim
npm install
# Expect: install proceeds (no preinstall error)
```
### Skip (env override):
```bash
# If needed, recreate the shim from the Fail step (10.7.9)
PATH="/tmp/npmshim:$PATH" \
VSCODE_SKIP_NPM_VERSION_CHECK=1 \
npm install
# Expect: install proceeds (npm gate skipped)
```




**Maintainer Preference Honored:**
- âœ… Extends existing `preinstall.js` validation (as requested by @deepak1556)
- âœ… Avoids `engines` field in `package.json` (as explicitly rejected by maintainers)
- âœ… Maintains single source of enforcement
- âœ… Minimizes maintenance burden

## Related

- Closes #252372
- Alternative to PRs #255060 and #260368 (which add `engines` field)

## Checklist

- [x] My code follows VS Code's [[coding guidelines](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Coding-Guidelines)]
- [x] Changes are minimal and focused on the specific issue
- [x] No pure formatting changes to unmodified code
- [x] Consistent with existing codebase patterns
- [x] Backwards compatible (all existing functionality preserved)
- [x] Includes appropriate error handling
- [x] Tested across different npm versions
- [x] Documentation in code explains the approach
- [x] Links to related issue (#252372)

title: Suggest widget: Bug fix - when widget is too tall, ensure larger of above and below space is used.
author: andr8928
body: **Issue addressed:** https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/152324 **Description:** Currently, when the suggest widget has enough space below, everything is fine: When the suggest widget is larger than the area below the current line, the current code always calculates the height and position of the widget using the space **above** the line (even if the space below is larger): With this change, if the suggest box is larger than the space below, it will now choose the largest of "above" and "below" to use in its calculations (unless force-above is enabled):

author: hihry
body:
fixes : #260539

This PR fixes an issue where sourceLabel in the discard edits confirmation dialog could remain unused or cause type warnings because it was potentially undefined.
Added a default localize('agentEditsLabel', 'Agent Edits') fallback to guarantee a string type.
Updated localize calls in the confirmation message to ensure placeholders ({0}, {1}) match arguments.
Prevents red-highlight warnings in the editor and ensures correct label display for both single and multiple file scenarios.

title: Fix OAuth redirect URI format to align with Microsoft's URL standards
author: bluedog13
body:
## OAuth Redirect URI Format Not Aligned with Microsoft's URL Standards

### Problem
VS Code's OAuth implementation generates redirect URIs without trailing slashes, while Microsoft's own OAuth 2.0 documentation and standards-compliant identity providers (including Entra ID) require trailing slashes in redirect URIs per RFC specifications.

This creates a mismatch where:
- **VS Code generates**: `http://127.0.0.1:3000`
- **IDP expects**: `http://127.0.0.1:3000/`

### Root Cause
Microsoft Entra ID (and other compliant IDPs) automatically append trailing slashes to redirect URIs during OAuth flows, following Microsoft's documented standards. However, VS Code's implementation returns URLs without trailing slashes, causing URI mismatch validation failures.

### Recent Change Context
A June 29th PR that modified `loopbackServer.ts` removed the trailing slash, introducing this standards compliance issue. This change made VS Code generate non-compliant redirect URIs that don't align with Microsoft's own OAuth 2.0 format requirements.

### Solution
This PR restores trailing slashes in two key locations:

1. **`loopbackServer.ts`** (line 105): Runtime redirect URI generation
2. **`oauth.ts`** (lines 739-746): Dynamic client registration redirect URIs

**Changes:**
- `http://127.0.0.1:${port}` â†’ `http://127.0.0.1:${port}/`
- `http://localhost` â†’ `http://localhost/`
- `http://127.0.0.1` â†’ `http://127.0.0.1/`
- `http://localhost:${port}` â†’ `http://localhost:${port}/`

### Impact
- Resolves OAuth authentication failures with "redirect_uri_mismatch" errors
- Ensures compatibility with standards-compliant OAuth providers
- Aligns VS Code with Microsoft's documented OAuth 2.0 URL format requirements

### Standards Reference
This change ensures VS Code follows Microsoft's own OAuth 2.0 redirect URI format requirements, improving compatibility with standards-compliant identity providers.

Fixes #260425

title: feat: add engines property to root package.json
author: rinilkunhiraman
body:
## Description

This PR adds the `engines` property to the root `package.json` to specify the required Node.js and npm versions for VS Code development, addressing issue #252372.

## Changes

- Added `engines` property with Node.js version `>=22.17.0` (matching the `.nvmrc` file)
- Added npm version `>=10.8.0` (compatible with the required Node.js version)
- This provides clear version requirements for contributors
- Helps prevent installation issues with unsupported Node.js/npm versions

## Why this change is needed

As mentioned in the original issue, the [How to Contribute](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute) guide mentions using `npm install` but doesn't specify which npm or Node.js versions are required. This change:

1. **Provides quick reference** for required versions
2. **Prevents errors** when using unsupported versions  
3. **Matches existing `.nvmrc`** specification (22.17.0)
4. **Follows npm standards** for version specification

## Testing

- [x] Verified the `engines` field is valid JSON
- [x] Confirmed Node.js version matches `.nvmrc` 
- [x] Verified npm version is compatible with Node.js 22.17.0
- [x] No breaking changes - this is purely additive metadata

## Associated Issue

Fixes #252372

title: fix(sourcemap): normalize paths to avoid duplicated prefixes like filâ€¦
author: hihry
body:
fixes : #251233
### Problem

When building with esbuild and gulp-sourcemaps, the generated `.map` files often include:

- `file:///` prefixes in `sources`
- Full absolute paths like `/home/user/vscode/src/vs/...`

These break debugging tools and create duplicated or corrupted paths when loading source maps in the editor or browser.
### Solution

This PR fixes the sourcemap path normalization by:

- Removing `file:///` prefixes from `sourceMap.sources`
- Replacing long absolute `/src/...` paths with the expected `vs/...` format

title: fix: re-install command on macOS via elevation
author: deepak1556
body:
Fix situation when code command was overwritten to a different application and attempting to reinstall the command from VSCode would throw an error. This is because we tried to unlink as a normal user which would return `EACCES`. The action to create symlink is performed via elevation and `-sf` will override an existing symlink, so we can instead retry directly with the elevation prompt path when the target is different.

/cc @isidorn

title: fix: use readable name for SCM status bar entries on GitHub.dev (#259â€¦
author: hihry
body:
Fixes #259649

### Problem
On GitHub.dev, the SCM status bar entries showed internal identifiers like `status.scm.0` instead of readable labels.

### Solution
Ensured the `name` field of each `IStatusbarEntry` is properly set to a readable string like `Source Control: Sync` or `Source Control: SwitchToBranch`, falling back to the command title if no repo-agnostic name is found.

This ensures GitHub.dev's status bar menu does not fall back to internal IDs as visible labels.

title: feat(scm): Customizable SCM Graph History Item Formatting (GitLens-style Variable Support)
author: Zahariel1942
body:
### Overview

This PR implements customizable formatting for SCM Graph History items in VS Code #255719, allowing users to personalize how commit history is displayed in the Source Control Graph view. Inspired by GitLens, it introduces a configuration option for variable-based formatting, enabling greater flexibility and clarity for teams and individuals.

### Key Changes

#### 1. Configuration Setting

Added `"scm.graph.historyItemFormat"` to `src/vs/workbench/contrib/scm/browser/scm.contribution.ts`:

- **Type:** `string`
- **Description:** Controls the format of each history item in the Source Control Graph view. Supports variables:
  - `${author}` â€” Commit author name
  - `${authorEmail}` â€” Author email
  - `${subject}` â€” Commit subject/title
  - `${message}` â€” Full commit message
  - `${hash}` â€” Full commit hash
  - `${displayId}` â€” Shortened commit hash
  - `${date}` â€” Relative date (e.g., "2 hours ago")
  - `${timestamp}` â€” Full timestamp

**Examples:**
- `${subject}`
- `${displayId} - ${subject}`
- `${author} â€¢ ${subject}`
- `[${displayId}] ${subject} by ${author}`
- `${subject} (${date})`

#### 2. Formatting Function

Introduced `formatHistoryItem` in `src/vs/workbench/contrib/scm/browser/util.ts`:

- Replaces variables in the format string with actual commit data.
- Handles missing values gracefully (empty string fallback).
- Preserves line breaks in commit messages.
- Removes trailing spaces for clean appearance.

#### 3. Renderer Integration

Updated `HistoryItemRenderer` in `src/vs/workbench/contrib/scm/browser/scmHistoryViewPane.ts`:

- Observes configuration changes for `"scm.graph.historyItemFormat"` using VS Code's observable pattern.
- Uses `autorun` for real-time UI updates when settings change.
- Applies custom formatting via `formatHistoryItem`.

#### 4. Comprehensive Testing

Added test coverage in `src/vs/workbench/contrib/scm/test/browser/util.test.ts`:

- Tests all supported variables.
- Validates default and multi-variable formats.
- Checks handling of missing values and edge cases.
- Includes GitLens-style example formats.

title: Add support for a help link when MCP assisted installation fails
author: joelverhagen
body: This is in support of https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/257679. This will also support https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/259901 if, for example, we move to using `npm` for the "does the package exist" check and npm is not available. I am working in using the server.json contained in NuGet packages to improve MCP installation. To do these, I need to invoke `dotnet tool install` commands to download the package. If the user does not have `dotnet` installed, we should let them known. This is prior to the MCP server being installed so the existing notification flow will not kick in yet. The URL and label are optionally sent back as part of the error. I believe this is a useful additional to the contract of `github.copilot.chat.mcp.setup.validatePackage`. It looks like this: Also, added `dotnet` to the list of recognized missing commands in case `dotnet tool exec` is used. Also, fix a misnamed editor service dependency.

title: Fix sticky scroll hover listeners piling up
author: aryla
body:
The StickyScrollWidget adds new mouse enter/exit listeners on every render without clearing the old ones so the listeners keep accumulating. Rendering gets very slow once the number of listeners reaches 100000. Fixed by clearing the existing listeners before adding new ones.

title: ðŸ’„ Todo list widget: Muted design and progress scrolling
author: digitarald
body:
## Summary

Enhances the chat todo list widget with comprehensive UX improvements including progress indicators, smart scrolling, and refined styling.

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c10b7dcc-8baa-4625-9bfa-8263566c3cc4


## Changes

### Core Features
- **Progress Indicator**: Changes "Tasks" â†’ "Todos" with dynamic progress display (e.g., "Todos (2/5)")
- **Smart Scrolling**: Auto-scrolls to relevant items with workflow-aware positioning
- **Refined Styling**: Less prominent header with compact, muted appearance

### Technical Improvements
- **TypeScript**: Added `getProgressText()` method and `scrollToRelevantItem()` with intelligent positioning logic
- **CSS**: Responsive sizing using `calc(6.5 * 24px)`, scroll snap behavior, and modern scrollbar styling
- **UX**: Shows 6.5 items with half-line affordance, prioritizes in-progress items, handles edge cases

### Behavior
- **Empty state**: Shows "Todos" 
- **With progress**: Shows "Todos (X/Y)" format
- **Scrolling**: Centers active items, shows completed context, scrolls to top when all items are not-started
- **Responsive**: Uses VS Code's standard calc() patterns for maintainable sizing

## Testing
- âœ… TypeScript compilation successful
- âœ… Follows VS Code localization patterns
- âœ… Maintains existing widget functionality
- âœ… CSS follows VS Code design system

title: Migrates from stack trace processing to DebugLocation
author: hediet
body:
The stack trace processing approach used file and method name conventions to detect the location of an observable.
This would break when the code is bundled (e.g. in insiders).

With this PR, the DebugLocation class is introduced that fixes this.

title: Reversed diff editor order for comparing to clipboard
author: antondevson
body: Changes the editor pane order for comparing active file to clipboard, so that the clipboard is on the right (modified) instead of left (original) side. This is to reflect the behavior of all the other `Compare...` commands where the active file is on the left. This is the simplest fix for issue https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/259434 if it is to be considered a bug, which is indicated by the behavior of the other similar commands. Regarding changing the localization key, I'm not sure if this is needed or not as I'm unaware of how such a change in the message prompts updates for translations, please correct if not needed.

title: Fix theme not being synchronized with external windows on firefox
author: CGNonofr
body:
fix #259835

<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->

Firefox doesn't allow to watch style element content using a MutationObserver. A MutationObserver is used to synchronize main windows styles with external windows. As a consequence, the theme is not properly updated on external windows on Firefox.

As a workaround, also add a data-hash attribute on the style elements, and watch it as well in the MutationObserver

title: feat: Introduce ILN - Revolutionary Language Unification Extension
author: Tryboy869
body:
# ðŸŒŒ Revolutionary Feature: ILN Language Unification for VS Code

## Problem Solved
Modern development requires mastering numerous languages for different paradigms (Go for concurrency, Rust for safety, Python for AI, etc.), creating significant friction.

## Solution: ILN (Informatique Language Nexus)
This PR introduces a VS Code extension for ILN, a revolutionary system that unifies programming paradigms through "essences." It allows developers to use concepts from any language within a single, consistent syntax.

### Key Features
- **Intelligent Auto-completion** for ILN essences (`chan!`, `own!`, `ml!`, etc.).
- **Hover Documentation** explaining each paradigm.
- **Multi-language Support** (Python, JS, TS, Go, Rust, and more).

### Revolutionary Impact
- **Reduces learning curve** by unifying paradigms.
- **Increases development speed** by eliminating context switching.
- **Introduces the ILN philosophy** to over 200M VS Code users.

This contribution is fully functional and has passed all compilation tests.

**Project Context:**
- **Official ILN Repository:** [https://github.com/Tryboy869/iln-nexus](https://github.com/Tryboy869/iln-nexus)
- **Author:** Tryboy869

The future of programming is unified. The future is ILN.

title: Fix notebook code actions on save not triggering for LSP servers
author: MarthinusBosman
body:
Fixes #216653 and astral-sh/ruff-vscode#51 where code actions (like source.organizeImports and source.fixAll) from LSP servers like Ruff were not being triggered when saving notebook files.

The problem was that notebook save participants were using CodeActionTriggerType.Invoke for all code actions, but many LSP servers filter their actions based on trigger type.

This change uses different trigger types based on the code action kind:
- CodeActionTriggerType.Invoke for notebook-specific actions (notebook.*) to preserve cross-cell editing capabilities (addresses #183855)
- CodeActionTriggerType.Auto for regular LSP actions (source.*) to match standard save participant behavior

Resolves issues with extensions like Ruff not organizing imports or applying fixes on notebook save when configured in notebook.codeActionsOnSave.

title: Avoid re-sanitizing markdown during rendering
author: mjbvz
body:
Currently rendering markdown sanitizes the content twice. When creating the output element it also goes: `string -> dom-> string -> dom` (with other hops potentially in the implementation)

This change changes to a single pass that goes `string -> dom` with a single sanitize call. Since we are moving away from DomParser, the output is slightly changed

title: Support server.json being returned by assisted MCP install
author: joelverhagen
body:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->

This works around the lack of https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/259100 and is progress on https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/257679. There will be a separate PR on the chat extension to support server.json in NuGet packages.

It enhances the `github.copilot.chat.mcp.setup.flow` command to have an additional `type` property. When this type property is set to `"server.json"`, the result is treated as an MCP Registry server.json and mapped to the VS Code configuration format. If the `type` property is falsey set or set to `"vscode"`, the existing codepath is used.

Additionally, I updated the `toScannedMcpServerAndInputs` to be a public static method so it can be called after the `github.copilot.chat.mcp.setup.flow` command returns. 

I noticed the resulting `args` and `env` placeholder values had the format `{input:foo}`, instead of format `${input:foo}`. Based on https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/reference/variables-reference#_input-variables, it seems like this was a bug in the original implementation, but I may be wrong. @sandy081 - could you confirm?

Verified with:
- npm: `@azure/mcp` (old flow, no server.json)
- Python: `mcp-server-fetch` (old flow, no server.json)
- Docker: `mcp/node-code-sandbox` (old flow, no server.json)
- NuGet: `NuGet.Mcp.Server` (new flow), `Knacode.SampleMcpServer` (new flow, this one has an input)

body:
#259566 

This PR updates the hover text for the Restore to Last Checkpoint action to follow the project's capitalization guidelines. Specifically, it ensures that all major words are capitalized, except for short words like "to", in line with the style rules.

Changes

Updated hover label from Restore to last checkpoint â†’ Restore to Last Checkpoint.

Rationale
The existing hover text did not follow the UI capitalization conventions used in the project. This change improves consistency and adheres to the design and style guidelines.

Before
Restore to last checkpoint

After
Restore to Last Checkpoint

title: fix: position terminal icon picker dynamically based on trigger source
author: sanchitkhthpalia
body:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.

-->

This PR fixes the placement issue with the terminal icon picker widget, as discussed in #211083.

âœ… **Changes made:**
- Updated `TerminalIconPicker` so it now accepts a `source` parameter (`'commandPalette'` or `'terminalTab'`).
- The picker is now dynamically positioned:
  - **When triggered via the command palette**: appears centered below the command center.
  - **When triggered via the terminal tab**: appears near the terminal tab area.
- Adjusted `TerminalInstance.changeIcon` to call the picker with the correct source.

ðŸ“Œ **Why:**
Previously, the icon picker always appeared near the top center, which could look odd or be partially hidden.
This makes the UX more intuitive by placing the picker close to where it was triggered.

âœ… **How to test:**
- Trigger the terminal icon picker via the terminal tab âžœ it should appear near the tab area.
- Trigger via the command palette âžœ it should appear centered below the command center.

---

**Fixes:** #211083  
âœ”ï¸ Allows edits by maintainers

title: Don't refresh cached globals automatically
author: Tyriar
body: It turns out that on Windows the `exec` calls can end up blocking the exthost for over a second: This is likely due to Windows Defender, but adding node to exclusions didn't seem to help. Because of this, plus we shouldn't be launching processes so often, the caching now must be explicitly cleared in order to get the latest. This is just a limitation we'll have to include in the documentation (https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-docs/issues/8700). Fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/259343 Fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/256746 Merge first: - https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/259347 - https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/259350 Before (after reload, ext host initialized): ![Recording 2025-08-03 at 05 18 39](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ad79c813-02da-4fae-b205-393e6ea0f5b9) After (after reload, ext host initialized): ![Recording 2025-08-03 at 05 17 23 (1)](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/9769f1c7-0c0a-4678-b8d3-a026bb1d2589)

title: fix: tiny memory leak in debugToolBar.ts
author: alexkozy
body:
`dispose(IDisposable[])` call disposes every element of the array but does not clear the array itself - but it returns an empty array. As a result `debugViewTitleItems` array accumulates all items and keep references to them forever.

There are two potential solutions:
- `debugViewTitleItems = dispose(debugViewTitleItems)`
- use DisposableStore

This commit implements the second one.

title: Restore alt+left/right keybinding to switch terminal pane
author: Tyriar
body:
This was caused due to the new approach for mapping alt+arrow to ctrl using VS Code keybindings, rather than being built into xterm.js. This unfortunately meant it regressed behavior for navigating terminal panes using alt+left/right (or up/down) which is a long established keybinding. The fix was a decent size, here's what it includes:

- Changing the weight so the pane nav keybindings win out
- Adding a when clause to the pane nav keybindings so they're disabled unless you're in a split pane
- Adding a new context key since the existing one that sounds correct is specific to the _focused_ tab and is primarily there to drive the tab context menu

Fixes #259326

title: Restore alt+left/right keybinding to switch terminal pane
author: Tyriar
body:
This was caused due to the new approach for mapping alt+arrow to ctrl using VS Code keybindings, rather than being built into xterm.js. This unfortunately meant it regressed behavior for navigating terminal panes using alt+left/right (or up/down) which is a long established keybinding. The fix was a decent size, here's what it includes:

- Changing the weight so the pane nav keybindings win out
- Adding a when clause to the pane nav keybindings so they're disabled unless you're in a split pane
- Adding a new context key since the existing one that sounds correct is specific to the _focused_ tab and is primarily there to drive the tab context menu

Fixes #259326

---

Verified:

- Right click context menu features the Unsplit action correctly for split pane terminals, but not in regular ones
- Alt+left/right navigates words in the shell when a single terminal is opened
- Alt+left/right navigates panes when a split terminal pane is active
- Alt+up/down navigates panes immediately after moving the panel to the side bar

title: Async iterable migration
author: hihry
body:
### Summary

Fixes #256854
This PR refactors code to replace all usages of `AsyncIterableObject` with `AsyncIterableProducer` to align with the updated async iteration API in VS Code.

### Changes
- Updated method signatures and return types to use `AsyncIterableProducer`.
- Migrated relevant `AsyncIterableObject` instantiations to `AsyncIterableProducer`.
- Adjusted import statements accordingly.
- Verified that behavior remains consistent after migration.

### Rationale
`AsyncIterableProducer` is now the preferred class for async iteration in VS Code. This migration helps improve memory efficiency and reduces the risk of potential memory leaks in async iteration scenarios.

title: Important fix for resource validation in MCP
author: TylerLeonhardt
body:
In this example:

MCP url: https://foo.com/mcp
WWW-Auth resource_metadata: https://foo.com/laugh/in/the/face/of/conventions.json
PRM: https://foo.com/laugh/in/the/face/of/conventions.json
PRM resource property: https://foo.com/mcp

I use to do:
a URL derived from "WWW-Auth resource_metadata" (which is actually just PRM) is compared to "PRM resource property"

but instead it should be:

"MCP url" compared to "PRM resource property"

Which is what this PR addresses

ref https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9728#section-3.3

title: Fix remote and multi-root issues with task tools
author: meganrogge
body: 1) Task tools weren't working for remotes It can take longer in a remote window for the tasks service to update after a config change, such as when a task is added to the `tasks.json`. Before, we had a static timeout of 200 ms. Now, we poll for up to 5 seconds to wait for the task to be discovered. The key for tasks in a remote window is different from the local case, so we have to parse the URI to check for the workspace folder 2) Task tools weren't working for mult-root repos, just needed to loop over all folders to find task config fixes #258720 fixes #258723 fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/259014

title: Fix --commit-id flag for code serve-web
author: justin39
body:
Fixes a bug where passing --commit-id during `code serve-web` would prevent serve-web from downloading a new version of the client at all.

See [this comment](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/255218#issuecomment-3137695656) from #255218 for additional context.

title: Handle worktree errors
author: nguyenchristy
body: Fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/258557#event-18883432995 and https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/258619#event-18884722720 This PR handles 2 separate kinds of worktree errors: (1) when a user wants to create a worktree at a path where a worktree already exists and (2) if a user attempts to check out a branch that already has a worktree. Shows: 1) Checking out branch that is currently used by worktree 2) Creating worktree at a path where a worktree already exists 3) Checking out a branch that already has a worktree 4) Creating a worktree by checking out a branch you're currently on https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/26cf37b9-efb1-4516-a65a-39763652bfab

title: fix: preserve OAuth subpaths in endpoint construction per RFC 8414
author: arjunkmrm
body:
Dev from https://smithery.ai here ðŸ‘‹! We noticed a bug when testing our server's OAuth flow where subpaths were being dropped when creating OAuth endpoints. This PR fixes `getDefaultMetadataForUrl` to preserve them per rfc 8414 section 3: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8414#section-3

Authorization servers supporting metadata MUST make a JSON document containing metadata as specified in Section 2 available at a path formed by inserting a well-known URI string into the authorization server's issuer identifier between the host component and the path component, if any. By default, the well-known URI string used is "/.well-known/oauth-authorization-server". This path MUST use the "https" scheme. The syntax and semantics of ".well-known" are defined in RFC 5785 [RFC5785]. The well-known URI suffix used MUST be registered in the IANA "Well-Known URIs" registry [IANA.well-known].

## Issue

See https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/258845

OAuth servers hosted at subpaths (e.g., `https://api.example.com/oauth/server`) were having their paths dropped:

```typescript
// Before (broken)
Input: https://api.example.com/oauth/server
Output: https://api.example.com/authorize 

// After (fixed)  
Input: https://api.example.com/oauth/server
Output: https://api.example.com/oauth/server/authorize 
```

## Changes

- Preserve existing paths in `getDefaultMetadataForUrl`
- Add RFC 8414 reference

Fixes the same issue as [modelcontextprotocol/typescript-sdk#687](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/typescript-sdk/pull/687).

See tests in `src/vs/base/test/common/oauth.test.ts`

title: Only change the line height of the view line
author: remcohaszing
body: Previously, if a decoration specified a custom line height, this affected all viewlines that are covered by model line. Now the line height is only applied to the view lines that render the decoration. It is still possible to change the line height of an entire view line by setting the decoration option `isWholeLine`. Closes #249967 cc @aiday-mar

title: Fix soft wrapping on \n
author: RedCMD
body:
almost Fixes #258022
I haven't been able to understand all the code yet
so soft wrapping seems to only work for 40% of `\n` when changing the editor size
cc @alexdima @rfon6ngy 

* #258022
* fixed wrapping going haywire when changing editor size
* added the `\n` softwrap check to `createLineBreaksFromPreviousLineBreaks()`, which handles word wrap while the editor is changing size (#258022)
* fixed wrapping in large files
  test https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/main/extensions/typescript-basics/syntaxes/TypeScript.tmLanguage.json (minify json first)
* Fixed wrapping sometimes not working correctly with `"editor.wordWrap": "bounded"/"wordWrapColumn"` (extending well past the 80char limit)
* extracted out the `lineText.includes('"')` check, so we don't have to recompute it on every single `\n`
* fixed wrapping when there was a escaped backslash before the `\n`
  `"\\\n"` now works

title: fix: align counter element
author: rzhao271
body:
This PR aligns the counter element in the Settings editor for themes that do not have a defined contrast border.

Fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/258147.

title: Don't attempt to cancel command when basic SI is used
author: Tyriar
body:
Because of the complications that arise when ^C is sent to the shell, this change disables that functionality when basic SI is used. That means that the command will probably fail if the user types into the terminal, but that's an edge case vs almost everything failing without this change

Fixes #258294

title: fix: avoid leaking focus tracker
author: alexkozy
body:
While we dispose the tracker, we still hold the reference to it and the once event through the disposable array. It means that we will keep the focus tracker and everything related to it in memory until we dispose `WorkbenchContextKeysHandler`.

Fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/246173
